title: Combining Lorentz TEM and SEM with Polarization Analysis to Uncover Fractional Topological Spin Textures in Fe/Gd Multilayer Thin Films
content: We use a combination of scanning electron microscopy with polarization analysis (SEMPA) and Lorentz transmission electron microscopy (LTEM) to study magnetic skyrmions. Magnetic skyrmions have drawn significant research attention for their novel physics and their potential applications in spintronics and logic devices [1-4]. However, their practical potential has not been fully realized due to the difficulty of creating stable skyrmions in ambient conditions, and of achieving efficient current-driven mobility. Multilayer thin films have provided a solution to the former issue, allowing for a tunable skyrmion phase and leading to skyrmion lattices which are stable at room temperature and remanence [1]. However, the latter issue remains. This is in part because while magnetic skyrmions are fundamentally 2-dimensional, the materials that host them are 3-dimensional, and the resulting skyrmions are not necessarily uniform through the thickness of the material. In multilayer thin films, the helicity of the skyrmions’ domain walls (DWs) twists from Bloch-type in the bulk of the film to Néel-type at the surfaces [4] as a result of surface-volume stray field interactions (see Fig. 1). These Bloch DWs in the bulk combined with Néel caps create a structure known as a hybrid skyrmion which can significantly affect the response to a driving current [5]. In addition, the topology of this structure is novel and non-trivial, with a Hopf index – a 3-dimensional analog to the skyrmion index – of ±1/2.
